mnemonics.title: SALT for faster conduction
mnemonics.mnemonic: Saltatory conduction Accelerates with myelin, Large axon diameter, and Tight insulation
mnemonics.explanation: Summarizes why myelination speeds conduction: myelin allows current to jump between nodes, large diameters lower resistance, and tight insulation minimizes current loss.

mnemonics.title: CLOSeD until ready
mnemonics.mnemonic: Closed → depolarization opens → Open → time-dependent inactivation gate → Stuck (inactivated) → repolarization resets to Closed
mnemonics.explanation: Tracks the sequence of voltage-gated sodium channel states during an action potential.

mnemonics.title: SNARE SNAP
mnemonics.mnemonic: SNAREs Need Available calcium to Promote vesicle fusion
mnemonics.explanation: Reminds you that Ca²⁺ entry triggers synaptotagmin to clamp/unclamp SNARE complexes for vesicle fusion.

mnemonics.title: PASTA for active transport
mnemonics.mnemonic: Primary uses ATP; Secondary Takes Advantage of a gradient
mnemonics.explanation: Distinguishes primary active transport (direct ATP hydrolysis) from secondary (uses pre-existing gradients).

mnemonics.title: ACTIN to start contraction
mnemonics.mnemonic: Action potential down T-tubule → Ca²⁺ release → Troponin binds Ca²⁺ → Inhibition lifted → myosiN binds

mnemonics.title: CAMK Light
mnemonics.mnemonic: Calcium binds Calmodulin → activates MLCK → Kinase phosphorylates light chains → crossbridge cycling
mnemonics.explanation: Captures the reliance on Ca²⁺/calmodulin and myosin light-chain kinase instead of troponin.

mnemonics.title: GAS for Gs
mnemonics.mnemonic: Gs → Adenylyl cyclase → increased cAMP → Stimulates PKA
mnemonics.explanation: Outlines the canonical stimulatory G protein cascade.

mnemonics.title: SENSOR → INTEGRATOR → EFFECTOR
mnemonics.mnemonic: Detect deviation → Compare to set point → Apply response
mnemonics.explanation: Basic negative feedback loop structure for physiological control.

mnemonics.title: E for Exercise
mnemonics.mnemonic: Epinephrine/exercise → increased heart rate, bronchodilation, and glucose mobilization
mnemonics.explanation: Links sympathetic activation to the classic fight-or-flight responses mediated by epinephrine.

mnemonics.title: FAST for cardiac output
mnemonics.mnemonic: Filling (preload) + Afterload + Stroke volume + Time (heart rate) shape output
mnemonics.explanation: Reminds you that cardiac output depends on preload, afterload, stroke volume determinants, and heart rate.

mnemonics.title: ADH Adds AquaPores
mnemonics.mnemonic: ADH → AQP2 insertion → More water reabsorption in collecting duct
mnemonics.explanation: Summarizes how vasopressin increases water permeability to concentrate urine.

questions.stem: Which factor most directly increases conduction velocity in a myelinated axon?
choices: Higher density of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels at internodes
Longer spacing between nodes of Ranvier up to a physiological limit
questions.explanation: Myelin allows nodes to be spaced farther apart while preserving depolarization, so fewer regenerations are needed. Internodes have low Na⁺ channel density and low leak.

questions.stem: The Na⁺/glucose cotransporter in the intestine is best described as which process?
choices: Primary active transport powered by ATP hydrolysis at the transporter
Secondary active transport driven by the Na⁺ gradient created by the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase
Facilitated diffusion independent of other gradients
questions.explanation: It couples glucose entry to the inward Na⁺ gradient established by the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase, making it secondary active symport.

questions.stem: What triggers synaptic vesicle fusion at a chemical synapse?
choices: Direct depolarization of the vesicle membrane
Binding of Ca²⁺ to synaptotagmin after voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels open
Accumulation of acetylcholine in the cleft
questions.explanation: Ca²⁺ entry through voltage-gated channels binds synaptotagmin, which modulates SNARE complexes to drive fusion.

questions.stem: During skeletal muscle contraction, tropomyosin moves because:
choices: Calcium binds troponin C, changing the troponin-tropomyosin complex
ADP release from myosin pushes it aside
questions.explanation: Ca²⁺ binds troponin C, altering the troponin complex so tropomyosin shifts to expose actin binding sites.

questions.stem: Which event is essential for initiating crossbridge cycling in smooth muscle?
choices: Phosphorylation of myosin light chains by MLCK
questions.explanation: Smooth muscle relies on Ca²⁺/calmodulin activation of MLCK, which phosphorylates myosin light chains to permit cycling.

choices: Baroreceptor-mediated reduction of sympathetic outflow after blood pressure rises
questions.explanation: Baroreceptor activation reduces sympathetic tone to counteract elevated blood pressure, opposing the original change.

questions.stem: An increase in venous return will most directly increase stroke volume through which mechanism?
choices: Stretching ventricular fibers to enhance crossbridge formation
Reducing heart rate to allow longer filling
questions.explanation: Greater venous return increases end-diastolic volume, stretching ventricular fibers and boosting force via the Frank-Starling mechanism.

questions.stem: Which receptor is primarily responsible for bronchodilation during sympathetic activation?
questions.explanation: β2 adrenergic receptors on airway smooth muscle mediate bronchodilation in response to sympathetic signals.

questions.stem: Name two reasons refractory periods prevent action potentials from immediately re-firing at the same site.
questions.explanation: Voltage-gated Na⁺ channels are inactivated until repolarization, and the after-hyperpolarization raises threshold because many channels remain inactivated while K⁺ conductance stays high.

questions.stem: List two differences between primary and secondary active transport.
questions.explanation: Primary active transporters hydrolyze ATP directly at the transporter (e.g., Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase). Secondary active transporters use a gradient created by a primary pump to drive co-transport or counter-transport.

questions.stem: How does increasing extracellular Mg²⁺ affect NMDA receptor-mediated EPSPs?
questions.explanation: Higher Mg²⁺ strengthens the voltage-dependent block of NMDA channels, so more depolarization is required to relieve the block and EPSCs are smaller.

questions.stem: Why can smooth muscle maintain tone with low ATP use?
questions.explanation: After myosin is dephosphorylated, crossbridges can enter a latch state with slow detachment, sustaining force with minimal ATP consumption.

questions.stem: Name two effects of angiotensin II that raise blood pressure.
questions.explanation: Angiotensin II constricts arterioles, stimulates aldosterone to retain Na⁺, increases thirst, and promotes ADH release to conserve water.

questions.stem: List two factors that increase cardiac contractility.
questions.explanation: Sympathetic stimulation via β1 receptors raises intracellular Ca²⁺ and increases inotropy; circulating catecholamines have similar effects.

flashcards.back: Membrane voltage at which inward Na⁺ current exceeds outward current, triggering regenerative channel opening.

flashcards.front: What maintains resting membrane potential in neurons?
flashcards.back: High K⁺ permeability through leak channels and the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase maintaining gradients.

flashcards.front: Give an example of primary active transport.
flashcards.back: Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pumping 3 Na⁺ out and 2 K⁺ in per ATP.
Carrier-mediated transport down an electrochemical gradient without ATP use.

flashcards.front: Role of acetylcholinesterase at the neuromuscular junction?
flashcards.back: Rapidly hydrolyzes acetylcholine to terminate signaling and prevent desensitization.

flashcards.front: What is the power stroke triggered by?
flashcards.back: Release of inorganic phosphate from the myosin head after binding to actin.
Ca²⁺-calmodulin binding shifts MLCK into its active conformation to phosphorylate myosin light chains.
A preemptive response to an anticipated change, reducing reliance on feedback error signals.

flashcards.front: Which receptors mediate most parasympathetic effects on organs?
flashcards.back: Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, especially M2 in the heart and M3 in smooth muscle/glands.
The percentage of end-diastolic volume ejected per beat (stroke volume ÷ EDV).

flashcards.front: Where is most filtered glucose reabsorbed?
flashcards.back: In the proximal tubule via Na⁺/glucose symporters.

flashcards.front: What is the primary action of aldosterone on the nephron?
flashcards.back: Increases Na⁺ reabsorption and K⁺ secretion in the distal nephron, raising water retention.
